      Enter your answer here:

Correct! 163

The correct answer is \(163\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=-6, f_n-f_{n-1}-2\), for \(n≥2\). Which of the following gives the nth term for \(n≥0\)?

Correct! \(a_{n}=-6+(n-1)(-2) \)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2–4.17.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(a_{n}=-6+(n-1)(-2) \). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=-20, f_n=f_{(n-1)}+5\) for \(n≥2\). Which of the following is the nth term?

Correct! \(a_{n}=-20+(n-1)(5)\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(a_{n}=-20+(n-1)(5)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence is defined recursively by \(f_1=3, f_n=2 \cdot \;f_{n-1}, n\geq2\). Which of the following gives the nth term for \(n≥0\)?

Correct! \(f(n)=3 \cdot 2^{n-1} \)

Try again. Work smarter, not harder! Take a moment to think about what you learned in activities 4.17.2–4.17.5. Are you using it the right way?

The correct answer is \(f_n=3⋅2^(n-1)\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?

  1. A sequence of numbers is given by \(a_2=1,a_3=5,a_4=9,a_5=13,a_6=17\). Which equation can be used to find the nth term of the sequence?

Correct! \(4n-7\)

Try again. Why don’t you go back to activities 4.17.2–4.17.4 to test your understanding? Then come back and try this question again.

The correct answer is \(4n-7\). You seem to be stuck. Who can you ask for help?
